actual.value: Regional peer-learning. Due to COVID-19 and restrictions on international travel no regional peer learning workshops have been organised so far. 2020-2021 target includes one regional peer-learning workshop in Latin America and one in Asia. However 5 virtual dialogues and peer learning events were held in 2020 and 2021 covering topics such as Fintech, Energy Efficiency Finance Platforms and Protocols and Blended Finance that have targeted CEFIM countries and beyond. These events were international in focus and open to all CEFIM countries and other interested parties. The CEFIM team will continue to explore opportunities to hold virtual events to reach a wide audience and when international travel restrictions are eased will explore opportunities to organise regional peer-learning workshops. These will likely focus on Asia as 5 of the 7 countries the CEFIM programme operates are in Asia.

title.narrative: Outcome 1: Strengthened domestic policy frameworks and enabling conditions for clean energy finance and investment.

Quality improvements of the domestic policy framework for clean energy finance and investment along three qualitative criteria: a) Coherent and consistent policies in place or strengthened b) Legislation/regulation in place (no major barriers exist) or improved (fewer barriers exist) c) Full-fledged or improved implementation of policies/programs/plans/enforcement of regulatory measures

target.value: Existing domestic policy framework for clean energy finance and investment improved compared to baseline. a) The government has improved existing legislation/regulation or set new and improved legislation/regulation, for at least 2 pieces of legislation/regulation, each addressing inconsistencies or incoherence within core climate/energy policies or broader investment conditions. b) Implementation and enforcement has improved for at least two policies/regulations/programmes/plans.

title.narrative: Outcome 2: Increased private sector activity in development and financing of "bankable" clean energy investments.

a) Improved dialogue, matchmaking and capacity between investors, project developers and policy makers to deliver and finance bankable clean energy projects. b) Improved pipeline of bankable clean energy projects. c) Number of financial institutions that have engaged in workshops or in investment due diligence, partnership or initial investment process in relevant clean energy projects as a result of the Programme. The OECD will measure the Outcome 2 indicator by undertaking a short survey of private investors and other private stakeholders.

target.value: a) Improved capacity regarding, and understanding by investors of, bankable investment opportunities in relevant clean energy projects. b) Improved government capacity to develop pipelines of bankable clean energy projects and facilitate clean energy financing, e.g. through de-risking instruments. c) At least 50 financial institutions have engaged in workshops, initial discussions, due diligence, partnerships or initial investment processes in relevant clean energy projects as a result of the Programme.

title.narrative: Output 2: Targeted implementation support in the form of: a) policy advice to help governments translate Country Reviews recommendations into policy/regulation, to share good practice and to build capacity to facilitate clean energy investment; and b) policy liaison to help mobilise clean energy financing (relating to capacity building, coordination and cooperation of non-governmental stakeholder, and promotion of risk mitigation instruments and new business models)

In each of the five countries: - Number of targeted, ad hoc policy advice or analytical support activities (referred to as "policy advice" activities). - Number of targeted policy liaison, networking, capacity building, coordination and finance mobilisation activities (referred to as "policy liaison" activities) to connect people, experiences and institutions and facilitate clean energy financing. - To increase the number of public officials who have been directly engaged and benefited from advice and expert support. - To improve the quality of the domestic policy framework for clean energy finance and investment according to relative (not absolute) improvements along four qualitative criteria.

target.value: - Two targeted policy advice activities initiated across two countries - Two targeted policy liaison activities initiated across two countries - Four ongoing targeted policy advice and policy liaison activities in two countries.

title.narrative: Output 1: Clean Energy Finance and Investment Country Reviews and stakeholder engagement.

a) Engagement by government stakeholders through a cross-government approach, improved understanding of key challenges, support for Programme recommendations to strengthen policy frameworks. b) Number of Clean Energy Finance and Investment Country Reviews ("Country Reviews") published by the OECD and launched (one in each of the five countries) as provided below. c) Number of stakeholder engagement meetings held to support capacity building, dialogue and coordination across ministries and other stakeholders.

target.value: a) Country Review Process initiated in a new country. b) Four stakeholder workshops held across four countries.

actual.value: 2 Country Reviews published in 2021 for Indonesia and Viet Nam. India and Colombia both declined the development of a country review and requested a Roadmap (India) and Bioenergy (Colombia) report instead. Draft of Bioenergy report completed for Colombia. CEFI Roadmap for India underway. Three focus areas have been requested by the Government of India: energy efficiency in SMEs, offshore wind and green hydrogen. Thailand requested the development of a Roadmap and work began in Q4 2021 on this activity. The Government of Thailand has requested the roadmap focus on small scale renewables development in rural areas, while for energy efficiency the scope has yet to be decided.

target.value: a) Two Country Reviews published and launched in 2020; Country Review process initiated in two new countries. b) Six stakeholder engagement workshops held across four countries.
